name: BBCWorld
BBCWorld
text:
Scientists say the loss of ice in Greenland last year was ‚Äúunprecedented‚Äù, breaking the previous record by 15%

Experts say ongoing emissions of carbon are pushing Greenland into an era of more extreme melting

[Thread]

https://t.co/P0AzrYmj1V

name: BBCWorld
text:
Over the past 30 years, Greenland's contribution to global sea levels has grown significantly as ice losses increase

A major international report concludes it is losing ice seven times faster than it was during the 1990s

https://t.co/P0AzrYmj1V https://t.co/hN4guhyWjZ

name: BBCWorld
text:
According to a calculation by climate scientists the 2019 losses would be enough to cover the entire UK with around 2.5 metres of melt water

https://t.co/P0AzrYmj1V https://t.co/CzDRB3Xk0X

name: BBCWorld
text:
While 2019 broke the record, both 2018 and 2017 saw decreased ice losses, lower than any other two-year period since 2003

But, five of the years with the biggest mass loss have now occurred in the past decade

https://t.co/P0AzrYmj1V https://t.co/miCJ2nh0GO

name: BBCWorld
text:
"We need to prepare for an extra 10cm or so of global sea level rise by 2100 from Greenland"

Leeds University's Prof Andy Shepherd says scientists need ‚Äúa new worst-case climate warming scenario, because Greenland is already tracking the current one"

https://t.co/P0AzrYmj1V https://t.co/YcNhIf4I6X

name: BBCWorld
text:
Using data from the Grace and Grace-FO satellites, as well as climate models, scientists suggest that during 2019, Greenland lost 532 gigatonnes of ice

Researchers say this loss is the equivalent of adding 1.5mm to global mean sea levels

https://t.co/P0AzrYmj1V https://t.co/sfQJPc4ASL

name: BBCWorld
text: Read the full report into the "extreme" ice loss in Greenland: https://t.co/P0AzrYmj1V

name: BBCWorld
text:
Traces of coronavirus have reportedly been found on packaging in China, and in food shipments in South America
 
It‚Äôs led to a lot of speculation about whether coronavirus can be transmitted via food packaging
 
So, what do we know?

[Thread]

https://t.co/tZV2tahGSX

name: BBCWorld
text:
In theory, it could be possible to catch Covid-19 from packaging material
 
Lab-based studies have shown the virus can survive for hours, even days, on some packaging materials like cardboard and various forms of plastics

https://t.co/tZV2tahGSX https://t.co/G8Ezo3JaX4

name: BBCWorld
text:
But, lots of scientists have questioned whether these results are true to life outside the lab
 
Professor Emanuel Goldman says ‚Äúthe chance of transmission through inanimate surfaces is very small‚Äù

https://t.co/tZV2tahGSX https://t.co/YgLy75W1RC

name: BBCWorld
text:
The virus is more stable at lower temperatures, which are typically used to transport food
 
But, in normal situations (ie outside of labs), environmental conditions change rapidly, meaning that the virus can't survive as long

https://t.co/tZV2tahGSX

name: BBCWorld
text:
The World Health Organization says there's "no confirmed case of Covid-19 transmitted through food or food packaging"
 
It says there is no need to disinfect packaging but "hands should be properly washed after handling food packages & before eating"

https://t.co/tZV2tahGSX https://t.co/deRRvTN3YL
